biccat

I heard something interesting on the radio last night, which led to an interesting bit of insight. It was suggested that a highschool kid said he was gay as a means of self-fulfillment.
 
 He "came out" and all of a sudden he got new friends who he previously thought were way too popular for him, received a lot of acceptance, and was generally admired for finally "accepting himself."
 
 Later, he decided he wasn't gay, and there wasn't so much as a whisper.
 
 Granted, this is likely an isolated incident, but the question remains: Do you believe that kids might "come out" just to get acceptance in their community and gain attention? Should we somehow look for these kids and try to give them some mental help (which they obviously would need if they're doing something so drastic)? If so, what should be done to stop this type of activity?
 
 We all know that the opposite happens, kids pretending to be straight who are really gay. But there's plenty of awareness (whether you agree with it or not) for homosexuality out there now, so lets try to keep this on track.
Jaxian

In places where homosexuality is widely accepted, I would not be surprised if some people claim to be homosexual as a means of gaining acceptance. I would expect this to stop happening only if homosexuality becomes widely accepted (which I do expect to happen eventually).
 
 As for this child, well I don't personally see any need for mental help for a child who claims to be homosexual in order to gain acceptance. I knew people who claimed to have had sex with girls in order to gain acceptance. I knew people who claimed their grades were better than they were to gain acceptance, or who claimed they didn't study as much as they really did. I knew all sorts of people who lied to gain acceptance back in school. I don't really think it qualified as reason to send them to therapy, though perhaps there is a better way to help children make friends (not one that I can list at the moment, though).
 
 There will also undoubtedly be people who think they are homosexual, then realize they aren't, as their sexual attractions and personalities mature. Finding yourself is part of growing up, and kids will sometimes think they're someone they aren't.
 
 But mental help? No, I don't think that is necessary, unless there are other problems, like depression or something.

 Hello everyone! Have not been on in awhile:) I hope your all well!
 Now
 onto the OP
 My son (14) has a friend whom we have suspected was gay.
 Recently he came out as it were, and has had no real problems.
 My son said to me he was glad he came out and respected him for that.
 This is just a minor example of how slowly but surely it is happening. Acceptance that is.

 The pro-life movement is (much like the President) opposed to use of embrionic stem cells; those taken from aborted fetuses. There is still government money available for stem cell research, so long as the cells aren't obtained from fetuses.
 
 The modern left has spun things so wildly out of control that they make it seem that Bush is opposed to all stem cell research and imposing an outright ban. The truth is (and I know you're going to hate hearing this) that Bush only stopped government sponsorship of embrionic stem cell research, for fear that it was government sponsorship of abortion.

Joe: 
 
 As I'm sure you're aware...I would echo your statements here as well. 
 
 I want the Government out of religious matters and vice versa.
